Full figure of young man dressed in short-sleeved polo-styled shirt, slacks, and shoes.  He looks off to the his left.  A dog sits near his right leg.  "Bedford Bronze Foundary Incorporated, New York" "Henry Kreis 1939" engraved on sculpture base.

Plaque text:
Henry Kreis received the commission for Young American Man and Young American Woman through a national competition held by the Section of Fine Arts which operated under the Treasury Department from 1938 to 1939 as one of President Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal programs.  The aim of the Section was to secure murals and sculpture for the embellishment of federal buildings. 

These two sculptures express the admirable qualities possessed by the young men and women of depression era America.  Kreis communicates the upstanding nature of the figures through his use of monumental, simple forms, leaving out any unessential or frivolous details.  Further evidence of their moral rectitude is cleverly expressed by Kreis' inclusion of the man's faithful dog, which regards his master with complete devotion.  Kreis won several other government commissions, including a 1935 national competition sponsored by the Section of Painting and Sculpture (1934-1938) for the United States Post Office in the Bronx, New York. He also completed two large marbles for the Stamford, Connecticut Housing Project as well as twelve relief panels for the Department of Justice in Washington, D.C.
